Message.Msg: Once_on: Just watched Fast Money. Lost respect for Brian Kelley, who I usually think is sharp. The assertion that consumers do not care about taxes is NOT supported by the facts. Significant front loading of purchases occurred in California before tax collection started. The run rate sales are skewed by the release of multiple new product platforms and slightly delayed launch of AAPL/GOOG competitive tablet offerings. And, Amazon's marketing budget is shooting through the roof (the number of Amazon ads on TV is crazy right now...), so if revenues AREN'T ramping hard, it is in DEEP trouble. While "gross margin" is higher on 3rd party sales, "gross profit" is lower. Amazon's "Fulfilled by Amazon" may drive up "gross margin" but it also drives up capital intensity in a big way. It essentially makes Amazon not a retailer, but a logistics competitor to UPS. Unlike UPS (which has built its facilities and fleets over decades out of cash flow), Amazon's scale in that arena is tiny. The reality is also that Google will encroach on Amazon's space with far greater cash and cash flow. Google is best positioned to reinvent retail/shopping because of the size of its ecosystem and the alignment of incentives amongst all of the players in the ecosystem... Watch the evolution of Google shopping, retailer/inventory integration and location based services. Google will offer more value to both consumers (via geographic inventory availability) and retailers (at a lower cost and in a wildly more capital efficient manner) and siphon "consumer purchase" traffic from Amazon over time. But, Amazon will be stuck amortizing all those investments in unnecessary facilities anyway... I'm in this for the long haul. I don't care if it runs back to 260. Google's approach here is simply superior. It's ecosystem is better positioned. Amazon already reached peak advantage. The financial media is doing EVERYTHING IT CAN to pump Amazon, but the reality is that most people like to purchase in person. If Google can ensure local product availability and competitive pricing with its approach, it will win and do so without #$%$ away billions in facilities that never should have been built anyway... Amazon already killed enough retail jobs with its predatory pricing abetted by fundamentally flawed tax structure. It is about to get payback from all retailers matching it on price and Google helping them to provide a superior solution to consumers in terms of convenience...

Topic.Title: AMZN growth concerns: They will add less revenue in 2012 than in 2011.

Message.Msg: There is much more to come... See my post on Google's approach and ecosystem. Trust me, Google is focused on Amazon, not Apple as its #1 target. The hundreds of millions of devices for Google were simply a means to extend its search/advertising dominance. Google Now and Shopping are going to provide a whole new level of value to advertisers and consumers alike. The bottom line is that Amazon has competed (with an unjust tax subsidy) with retailers. The vast majority will align behind a Google centric solution that minimizes channel conflict (Wal-Mart and Target would be wise to take the lead on such integration, as should category dominant big box players with big geographic footprints). Given their huge existing footprint and relative ease / leverage in connecting their systems to Google Shopping / Now, they could put a HUGE dent in Amazon's business and growth. Matter of (not too much) time before the next wave kicks in. Despite what everyone is saying, Amazon IS NOT very well positioned for it. Bring it on.

Message.Msg: Sybs: I wonder what would happen if every state pension fund got a letter asking them why they are invested directly or indirectly in Amazon, an entity that evades state taxes that has put many taxpaying entities out of business because of it. Even where it agreed to collect the taxes, it is trying to avoid collection on items financed, advertised and fulfilled by Amazon. Given all the California budget issues, I wonder what would happen if Calpers were to divest (both directly and indirectly). FMR wouldn't matter. With the necessary pension cuts that will be coming to state employees around the country, state Pension funds like Calpers have a fiduciary obligation to cut exposure to scams like this and level the playing field for retail businesses that collect sales tax, rather than creating an artificially low cost of capital for businesses that evade state sales tax, even after agreeing to collect it... after all, those taxes are needed to meet future pension obligations.
